Question: Nested Iterators: :I am trying to build a Space Invaders game and have developed this section of code to make all the aliens drop down when one of them hits the edge of the screen, however I'm getting a pretty nasty looking error message when it hits line Enemy de = downwardIterator.next();. The game still runs as it should, but it's firing off these error messages in the background when it hits that line.Here's the code:Iterator<Enemy> iterator = enemyList.iterator();    while (iterator.hasNext()) {        Enemy e = iterator.next();        if(e!=null && e.isActive()){            e.move();            e.draw(g);            if(e.edgeHit()){                Iterator<Enemy> downwardIterator = enemyList.iterator();                while (iterator.hasNext()) {                    Enemy de = downwardIterator.next();                    de.dropPosition();                    de.changeDirection();                }            }        }        else{            iterator.remove();        }    }e.move just makes the enemies move left and right.e.edgeHit detects when any enemy reaches the edge of the game screen.This is the full trace when it hits that line:Exception in thread "AWT-EventQueue-0" java.util.NoSuchElementException    at Question: Nested Iterators: :I am trying to build a Space Invaders game and have developed this section of code to make all the aliens drop down when one of them hits the edge of the screen, however I'm getting a pretty nasty looking error message when it hits line Enemy de = downwardIterator.next();. The game still runs as it should, but it's firing off these error messages in the background when it hits that line.Here's the code:Iterator<Enemy> iterator = enemyList.iterator();    while (iterator.hasNext()) {        Enemy e = iterator.next();        if(e!=null && e.isActive()){            e.move();            e.draw(g);            if(e.edgeHit()){                Iterator<Enemy> downwardIterator = enemyList.iterator();                while (iterator.hasNext()) {                    Enemy de = downwardIterator.next();                    de.dropPosition();                    de.changeDirection();                }            }        }        else{            iterator.remove();        }    }e.move just makes the enemies move left and right.e.edgeHit detects when any enemy reaches the edge of the game screen.This is the full trace when it hits that line:Exception in thread "AWT-EventQueue-0" java.util.NoSuchElementException    at Answer: The error is occurring because you are trying to call `iterator.next()` again in the same iterator that you are currently looping over. This is causing the NoSuchElementException because the iterator is already at the end of the list and there are no more elements to return.

To fix this, you should create a new iterator for the enemies that are going to drop down, and use that iterator to call `downwardIterator.next()`. Here's how you can modify your code:

```java
Iterator<Enemy> iterator = enemyList.iterator();
while (iterator.hasNext()) {
    Enemy e = iterator.next();
    if(e != null && e.isActive()){
        e.move();
        e.draw(g);
        if(e.edgeHit()){
            Iterator<Enemy> downwardIterator = enemyList.iterator();
            while (downwardIterator.hasNext()) {
                Enemy de = downwardIterator.next();
                de.dropPosition();
                de.changeDirection();
            }
        }
    } else {
        iterator.remove();
    }
}
```

This way, you're creating a new iterator for the enemies that are going to drop down, and you're using that iterator to call `downwardIterator.next()`. This should prevent the NoSuchElementException from occurring.

Also, it's worth noting that using `iterator.remove()` in a loop like this can lead to unexpected behavior. If you're removing elements from the list while you're iterating over it, you should use a `for-each` loop instead, like this:

```java
for (Enemy e : enemyList) {
    if (e != null && e.isActive()) {
        e.move();
        e.draw(g);
        if (e.edgeHit()) {
            for (Enemy de : enemyList) {
                de.dropPosition();
                de.changeDirection();
            }
        }
    } else {
        enemyList.remove(e);
    }
}
```

This way, you're not modifying the list while you're iterating over it, which can lead to more predictable behavior.
